title: Gastritis
body:
Gastritis occurs when the stomach lining becomes inflamed or irritated. Treatments depend on the cause and may include antacids, alginates, acid-suppressing medicines, or antibiotics. Untreated gastritis can progress to ulcers.

**Symptoms**
- Tummy pain
- Indigestion
- Bloating
- Nausea
- Vomiting
- Reduced appetite
- Increased burping or flatulence

**Causes**
- Helicobacter pylori infection
- Regular use of anti-inflammatory painkillers (ibuprofen, aspirin)
- Excessive alcohol intake
- Severe stress or illness (e.g., after surgery)
- Autoimmune conditions targeting the stomach lining

**Prevention**
- Reduce caffeine intake
- Elevate the head/shoulders with an extra pillow at night
- Lose weight if overweight
- Consult a doctor about long-term NSAID/aspirin use
- Do not eat within 3â€“4 hours of bedtime
- Avoid consuming acidic, fizzy, spicy, or fatty foods or drinks
- Avoid drinking alcohol
- Do not smoke

**When to see a doctor**
- Call 999 or go to A&E if you vomit bright red blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, produce black tarry stools, or develop sudden severe abdominal or chest pain
- Ask for an urgent GP appointment or NHS 111 help if you lose appetite, feel full after small meals, lose weight unintentionally, sense a lump in the abdomen, have painful/difficult swallowing, or keep vomiting
- See a GP if tummy pain or indigestion lasts longer than a week, worsens, or recurs
